metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Determination of limiting reactants or reagents in chemical reactions

limiting_reagent_definition.name: Limiting Reagent Definition
limiting_reagent_definition.correct: The limiting reagent is the reactant that is completely consumed first in a reaction, determining the maximum amount of product that can form.

the reactant present in the smallest mas.error: Mass alone doesn't determine limiting reagent.
the reactant present in the smallest mas.fix: You must convert to moles and compare using the stoichiometric ratio. A small mass of a light molecule could still be in excess.
the reactant present in the smallest mas.action: Always convert masses to moles before comparing reactants.

the reactant with the highest molar mass.error: Molar mass doesn't determine which reagent is limiting.
the reactant with the highest molar mass.fix: Limiting reagent depends on moles present vs moles required by the balanced equation.
the reactant with the highest molar mass.action: Focus on mole ratios, not molar masses.

the reactant that produces the most prod.error: The limiting reagent actually restricts product formation.
the reactant that produces the most prod.fix: The limiting reagent runs out first, stopping the reaction and limiting product yield.
the reactant that produces the most prod.action: Think: which ingredient runs out first stops you making more cakes?

the reactant added last.error: Order of addition doesn't determine limiting reagent.
the reactant added last.fix: Limiting reagent is about relative amounts compared to stoichiometric requirements.
the reactant added last.action: Compare moles available to moles required by the equation.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding what limits a reaction.
persistent.action: Use the cake analogy: 3 eggs + 2 cups flour per cake. If you have 6 eggs but 3 cups flour, flour is limiting (only 1.5 cakes possible).

excess_reagent_definition.name: Excess Reagent Definition
excess_reagent_definition.correct: The excess reagent is the reactant that remains after the limiting reagent is completely consumed.

the reactant present in the largest mass.fix: Excess reagent is whatever remains after the limiting reagent is used up. Must compare moles using stoichiometry.
the reactant present in the largest mass.action: Convert to moles, apply mole ratios, then identify what's left over.

the reactant that is completely used up.error: That describes the limiting reagent, not excess.
the reactant that is completely used up.fix: Excess reagent is NOT completely consumed. Some remains unreacted.
the reactant that is completely used up.action: Remember: Limiting = all used. Excess = some left over.

the most reactive substance.fix: Excess is about quantity relative to stoichiometric needs, not chemical reactivity.
the most reactive substance.action: Focus on mole ratios from the balanced equation.

the product formed in greatest amount.error: Excess reagent is a reactant, not a product.
the product formed in greatest amount.fix: Products are formed from reactants. Excess reagent is the leftover reactant.
the product formed in greatest amount.action: Identify reactants (left side of equation) vs products (right side).

persistent.gap: You're confusing excess with other concepts.
persistent.action: After reaction: limiting reagent = 0 remaining. Excess reagent = some remaining.

mole_ratio_application.name: Mole Ratio Application
mole_ratio_application.correct: To find the limiting reagent, divide the moles of each reactant by its coefficient. The smallest result indicates the limiting reagent.

compare masses directly.error: Masses can't be compared directly for stoichiometry.
compare masses directly.fix: Different substances have different molar masses. Must convert to moles first.
compare masses directly.action: Step 1: Convert all masses to moles using n = m/M.

compare moles directly without consideri.error: Ignoring coefficients gives wrong answers when ratios aren't 1:1.
compare moles directly without consideri.fix: Coefficients tell you how many moles of each reactant are needed per reaction 'unit'.
compare moles directly without consideri.action: For 2A + 3B ‚Üí C: divide n(A) by 2, divide n(B) by 3, then compare.

multiply moles by coefficients.error: You should divide by coefficients, not multiply.
multiply moles by coefficients.fix: Dividing normalises each reactant to 'reaction units'. Multiplying gives meaningless numbers.
multiply moles by coefficients.action: Think: how many complete reactions can each reactant support? That's moles √∑ coefficient.

use the coefficient of the product.error: Product coefficients don't determine limiting reagent.
use the coefficient of the product.fix: Use reactant coefficients only. Products form based on which reactant runs out.
use the coefficient of the product.action: Focus on the left side of the equation for limiting reagent determination.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the coefficient division method correctly.
persistent.action: For each reactant: calculate n √∑ coefficient. Smallest value = limiting reagent.

stoichiometric_calculation.name: Stoichiometric Calculation Method
stoichiometric_calculation.correct: Convert mass to moles using n = m/M, then use mole ratios from the balanced equation to find amounts of other species.

divide mass by coefficient.error: Mass must be converted to moles before using coefficients.
divide mass by coefficient.fix: First: n = m/M. Then: apply stoichiometric ratios.

multiply mass by molar mass.error: To get moles, divide by molar mass, not multiply.
multiply mass by molar mass.fix: n = m/M means moles = mass √∑ molar mass.
multiply mass by molar mass.action: Units check: g √∑ (g/mol) = mol. Multiplication gives g¬≤/mol.

use volume directly in mass calculations.error: Volume and mass are different quantities.
use volume directly in mass calculations.fix: For gases at SLC, use n = V/24.79. For solutions, use n = cV. For solids, use n = m/M.
use volume directly in mass calculations.action: Check what data you're given: mass, volume, or concentration.

skip the mole calculation.fix: All stoichiometric comparisons require moles. Can't skip this step.
skip the mole calculation.action: Always convert to moles first, then apply ratios.

persistent.gap: You're making errors in the mole calculation step.
persistent.action: Practice: n = m/M for solids/liquids, n = V/24.79 for gases at SLC, n = cV for solutions.

product_calculation_from_limiting.name: Product Calculation
product_calculation_from_limiting.correct: The amount of product formed is calculated using the moles of the LIMITING reagent and the stoichiometric ratio to the product.

using moles of excess reagent.error: Using excess reagent overestimates product yield.
using moles of excess reagent.fix: Only the limiting reagent determines maximum product. The excess is left over.
using moles of excess reagent.action: Identify limiting reagent first, then use its moles for product calculation.

using total moles of all reactants.error: Adding reactant moles together is chemically meaningless.
using total moles of all reactants.fix: Each reactant contributes differently based on stoichiometry. Use limiting reagent only.
using total moles of all reactants.action: Focus on limiting reagent moles √ó (product coefficient / limiting reagent coefficient).

using the average of both reactants.fix: The reaction stops when limiting reagent runs out. Only those moles matter.
using the average of both reactants.action: Find limiting reagent, use its moles, apply ratio to product.

using whichever gives the larger answer.error: The limiting reagent gives the SMALLER product amount, not larger.
using whichever gives the larger answer.fix: Limiting reagent restricts yield. It gives the maximum achievable product.
using whichever gives the larger answer.action: Limiting = bottleneck. Product is limited by the bottleneck, not the excess.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting limiting reagent to product calculation.
persistent.action: Rule: Always use limiting reagent moles to calculate product. Never use excess reagent.

complete_combustion_limiting.name: Complete Combustion Limiting Reagent
complete_combustion_limiting.formula: Fuel is limiting, O‚ÇÇ is excess
complete_combustion_limiting.correct: In complete combustion, the fuel is the limiting reagent and oxygen is in excess, ensuring all fuel is converted to CO‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇO.

oxygen is the limiting reagent.error: If oxygen is limiting, combustion is incomplete.
oxygen is the limiting reagent.fix: Complete combustion requires excess oxygen. Fuel must be limiting.
oxygen is the limiting reagent.action: Complete ‚Üí all fuel burns ‚Üí fuel is limiting. Incomplete ‚Üí not enough O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ is limiting.

both reactants are limiting.error: Only one reactant can be limiting in a reaction.
both reactants are limiting.fix: By definition, the limiting reagent is the ONE that runs out first.
both reactants are limiting.action: Compare moles: whichever runs out first is the single limiting reagent.

neither reactant is limiting.error: Unless exact stoichiometric amounts, one must be limiting.
neither reactant is limiting.fix: Only in rare cases of exact proportions is neither limiting. Usually one is.
neither reactant is limiting.action: If exactly stoichiometric amounts: both finish together. Otherwise, one is limiting.

the product CO‚ÇÇ is limiting.fix: Limiting reagent is a reactant that determines product amount. Products are formed, not consumed.
the product CO‚ÇÇ is limiting.action: Limiting reagent = reactant on left side of equation.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting limiting reagent to combustion type.
persistent.action: Memorise: Complete combustion = fuel limiting, O‚ÇÇ excess. Incomplete = O‚ÇÇ limiting, fuel excess.

incomplete_combustion_limiting.name: Incomplete Combustion Limiting Reagent
incomplete_combustion_limiting.formula: O‚ÇÇ is limiting, fuel is excess
incomplete_combustion_limiting.correct: In incomplete combustion, oxygen is the limiting reagent and fuel is in excess, producing CO or C (soot) along with CO‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇO.

fuel is the limiting reagent.error: If fuel is limiting with excess O‚ÇÇ, combustion would be complete.
fuel is the limiting reagent.fix: Incomplete combustion occurs when there's not enough oxygen to fully oxidise the fuel.
fuel is the limiting reagent.action: Incomplete ‚Üí insufficient O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí oxygen is limiting ‚Üí CO or C forms.

carbon monoxide is the limiting reagent.error: CO is a product, not a reactant.
carbon monoxide is the limiting reagent.fix: CO forms because oxygen is limiting. Products can't be limiting reagents.
carbon monoxide is the limiting reagent.action: CO is evidence that O‚ÇÇ was limiting, not itself a limiting reagent.

water is the limiting reagent.error: Water is a product of combustion, not a reactant.
water is the limiting reagent.fix: Limiting reagent must be a reactant. Water forms during the reaction.
water is the limiting reagent.action: Identify reactants (fuel + O‚ÇÇ) vs products (CO‚ÇÇ, H‚ÇÇO, CO, C).

the reaction has no limiting reagent.error: All reactions with non-stoichiometric amounts have a limiting reagent.
the reaction has no limiting reagent.fix: Incomplete combustion definitely has oxygen as the limiting reagent.
the reaction has no limiting reagent.action: The very definition of incomplete combustion is insufficient oxygen.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding why incomplete combustion occurs.
persistent.action: Root cause: not enough O‚ÇÇ. Therefore O‚ÇÇ is limiting. Result: CO and/or C (soot) forms.

excess_calculation.name: Calculating Excess Amount
excess_calculation.correct: To find excess remaining: calculate how much of the excess reagent reacted with the limiting reagent, then subtract from initial amount.

subtract limiting from excess directly.error: Can't subtract moles of different substances directly.
subtract limiting from excess directly.fix: Must use stoichiometric ratio to find how much excess reacted with the limiting reagent.
subtract limiting from excess directly.action: Step 1: Find moles of excess that reacted using mole ratio. Step 2: Subtract from initial.

the excess remaining equals the initial.error: Some excess reagent is consumed in the reaction.
the excess remaining equals the initial.fix: Excess reagent reacts with all of the limiting reagent. Only the leftover is 'excess remaining'.
the excess remaining equals the initial.action: Calculate: n(excess reacted) = n(limiting) √ó ratio, then subtract from initial.

multiply excess by the stoichiometric ra.error: You need to find how much excess reacted, then subtract.
multiply excess by the stoichiometric ra.fix: Use limiting reagent moles to find excess consumed, then subtract from initial excess.
multiply excess by the stoichiometric ra.action: n(excess remaining) = n(excess initial) ‚àí [n(limiting) √ó (excess coefficient/limiting coefficient)].

excess remaining is zero.error: By definition, excess reagent has some remaining.
excess remaining is zero.fix: The limiting reagent is zero after reaction. Excess reagent always has some left.
excess remaining is zero.action: If it's all used up, it was actually the limiting reagent, not excess.

persistent.gap: You're making errors calculating remaining excess.
persistent.action: Three steps: 1) Find limiting moles. 2) Calculate excess reacted using ratio. 3) Subtract from initial excess.

limiting_reagent_definition.title: Limiting Reagent Definition
limiting_reagent_definition.content: The limiting reagent (or limiting reactant) is the reactant that is completely consumed first in a chemical reaction. It determines the maximum amount of product that can be formed because once it runs out, the reaction stops regardless of how much of the other reactants remain.
keyPoints: Completely consumed first in the reaction
Determines maximum product yield
Must compare moles using stoichiometric ratios, not mass
Like the ingredient that runs out first when baking

excess_reagent_definition.title: Excess Reagent Definition
excess_reagent_definition.content: The excess reagent is any reactant that is not completely consumed in the reaction. After the limiting reagent is used up, some amount of the excess reagent remains unreacted. There can be multiple excess reagents in a reaction with more than two reactants.
keyPoints: Not completely consumed - some remains
Present in greater amount than required by stoichiometry
Does not affect product yield (limiting reagent does)
Can calculate the amount remaining after reaction

mole_ratio_application.title: Using Mole Ratios to Find Limiting Reagent
mole_ratio_application.content: To identify the limiting reagent, divide the moles of each reactant by its coefficient in the balanced equation. The reactant with the smallest result is the limiting reagent. This method normalises each reactant to 'reaction units' - how many complete reactions each can support.
mole_ratio_application.formula: Limiting reagent has smallest value of: n(reactant) √∑ coefficient
keyPoints: First convert all quantities to moles
Divide moles by coefficient for each reactant
Smallest result = limiting reagent
Works for any number of reactants

stoichiometric_calculation.title: Stoichiometric Calculations
stoichiometric_calculation.content: Stoichiometric calculations use mole ratios from balanced equations to determine amounts of reactants and products. The key formula for converting between mass and moles is n = m/M, where n is moles, m is mass in grams, and M is molar mass in g mol‚Åª¬π.
keyPoints: Always convert to moles before using ratios
n = m/M for solids and liquids
n = V/24.79 for gases at SLC (25¬∞C, 100 kPa)
n = cV for solutions (c in mol L‚Åª¬π, V in L)

product_calculation_from_limiting.title: Calculating Products from Limiting Reagent
product_calculation_from_limiting.content: The amount of product formed is always calculated using the moles of the limiting reagent, not the excess. Multiply the moles of limiting reagent by the ratio of (product coefficient / limiting reagent coefficient) to find moles of product.
keyPoints: Always use limiting reagent for product calculations
Using excess reagent overestimates yield
Apply stoichiometric ratio from balanced equation
Convert moles to mass using m = n √ó M

complete_combustion_limiting.title: Limiting Reagent in Complete Combustion
complete_combustion_limiting.content: In complete combustion, the fuel is the limiting reagent and oxygen is in excess. This ensures all the fuel is fully oxidised to carbon dioxide and water. Complete combustion releases maximum energy and produces no carbon monoxide or soot.
keyPoints: Fuel = limiting reagent
Oxygen = excess reagent
Products: only CO‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇO
Maximum energy release

incomplete_combustion_limiting.title: Limiting Reagent in Incomplete Combustion
incomplete_combustion_limiting.content: In incomplete combustion, oxygen is the limiting reagent and fuel is in excess. This means there is not enough oxygen to fully oxidise all the fuel, resulting in carbon monoxide (CO) and/or carbon (soot) as products instead of only CO‚ÇÇ.
incomplete_combustion_limiting.formula: Excess fuel + limited O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí CO‚ÇÇ + CO + C + H‚ÇÇO (incomplete)
keyPoints: Oxygen = limiting reagent
Fuel = excess reagent
Products include CO (toxic) and/or C (soot)
Less energy released than complete combustion

excess_calculation.title: Calculating Excess Reagent Remaining
excess_calculation.content: To find how much excess reagent remains after reaction: first calculate how much of the excess reagent reacted with the limiting reagent using the mole ratio, then subtract this from the initial amount of excess reagent.
excess_calculation.formula: n(excess remaining) = n(excess initial) ‚àí n(excess reacted)
